Aurora

once you've seen over the last few years

and so all

why we build Amazon Neptune which we

well as many other customers have lots

there's their new or small tables and so
what they tend to have to do is they

at the peak so they make sure that

and they usually don't attach an auto

cannibalizes revenue for us and so we

say you want to run it in demand and we

will stop charging you you pay by the

you need and you've been running

for all those other tables and customers

and this pattern is driven by the
millions and millions of sensors and

very interested in being able to
understand what's happening with those

time and so
people are interested in what we call
time series data and with time series
data each data point consists of a
timestamp and one or more attributes and
it really measures how things change
over time
it helps drive real-time decisions so
you can imagine give you some asset
where all the sudden the temperature has
changed significantly you might want to
take some action on that asset and you
see it across lots of things clickstream
data all kinds of IOT sensor readings
even devops data and the problem is as
more and more companies have this need

a database if you try and do it with a

it means that you have to build these
indexes which are really large and
clunky and are slow to query or the
schemas in relational databases are
rigid here and aren't flexible enough as
you keep adding more and more sensors
and also the relational databases don't
have the analytics pieces that you want
in time series like smoothing and
interpolation and approximation these
are all things that you don't have and
then if you look at the existing time
series either open source pieces or the
limited number of commercial services
they're they're either just really hard

really large and fast-growing IOT

fully managed time series data

so timestream is gonna change the
